\section{VI.D Quantum microstates}

In the previous sections we indicated several failures of classical statistical mechanics, which were heuristically remedied by assuming quantized energy levels, while still calculating thermodynamic quantities from a partition sum Z=∑nexp⁡(−βEn)Z=\sum_{n} \exp \left(-\beta E_{n}\right)Z=∑n​exp(−βEn​). This implicitly assumes that the micro-states of a quantum system are specified by its discretized energy levels, and governed by a probability distribution similar to a Boltzmann weight. This 'analogy' to classical statistical mechanics needs to be justified. Furthermore, quantum mechanics is itself inherently probabilistic, with uncertainties unrelated to those that lead to probabilities in statistical mechanics. Here, we shall construct a quantum formulation of statistical mechanics by closely following the steps that lead to the classical formulation.

Micro-states of a classical system of particles are described by the set of coordinates and conjugate momenta {p⃗i,q⃗i};\left\{\vec{p}_{i}, \vec{q}_{i}\right\} ;{p​i​,q​i​}; i.e. by a point in the 6N6 N6N -dimensional phase space. In quantum mechanics {q⃗i}\left\{\vec{q}_{i}\right\}{q​i​} and {p⃗i}\left\{\vec{p}_{i}\right\}{p​i​} are not independent observables. Instead:

  • The (micro-) state of a quantum system is completely specified by a unit vector ∣Ψ⟩|\Psi\rangle∣Ψ⟩, which belongs to an infinite dimensional Hilbert space. The vector ∣Ψ⟩|\Psi\rangle∣Ψ⟩ can be written in terms of its components ⟨n∣Ψ⟩\langle n \mid \Psi\rangle⟨n∣Ψ⟩, which are complex numbers, along a suitable set of ortho-normal basis vectors ∣n⟩.|n\rangle .∣n⟩. In the convenient notation introduced by Dirac, this decomposition is written as
∣Ψ⟩=∑n⟨n∣Ψ⟩∣n⟩|\Psi\rangle=\sum_{n}\langle n \mid \Psi\rangle|n\rangle∣Ψ⟩=n∑​⟨n∣Ψ⟩∣n⟩

The most familiar basis is that of coordinates ∣{q⃗i}⟩\left|\left\{\vec{q}_{i}\right\}\right\rangle∣{q​i​}⟩, and ⟨{q⃗i}∣Ψ⟩≡Ψ(q⃗1,…,q⃗N)\left\langle\left\{\vec{q}_{i}\right\} \mid \Psi\right\rangle \equiv \Psi\left(\vec{q}_{1}, \ldots, \vec{q}_{N}\right)⟨{q​i​}∣Ψ⟩≡Ψ(q​1​,…,q​N​) is the wave-function. The normalization condition is

⟨Ψ∣Ψ⟩=∑n⟨Ψ∣n⟩⟨n∣Ψ⟩=1, where ⟨Ψ∣n⟩≡⟨n∣Ψ⟩∗\langle\Psi \mid \Psi\rangle=\sum_{n}\langle\Psi \mid n\rangle\langle n \mid \Psi\rangle=1, \quad \text { where } \quad\langle\Psi \mid n\rangle \equiv\langle n \mid \Psi\rangle^{*}⟨Ψ∣Ψ⟩=n∑​⟨Ψ∣n⟩⟨n∣Ψ⟩=1, where ⟨Ψ∣n⟩≡⟨n∣Ψ⟩∗

For example, in the coordinate basis, we must require

⟨Ψ∣Ψ⟩=∫∏i=1Nddq⃗i∣Ψ(q⃗1,…,q⃗N)∣2=1\langle\Psi \mid \Psi\rangle=\int \prod_{i=1}^{N} d^{d} \vec{q}_{i}\left|\Psi\left(\vec{q}_{1}, \ldots, \vec{q}_{N}\right)\right|^{2}=1⟨Ψ∣Ψ⟩=∫i=1∏N​ddq​i​∣Ψ(q​1​,…,q​N​)∣2=1
  • Classically, various observables are functions O({p⃗i,q⃗i})\mathcal{O}\left(\left\{\vec{p}_{i}, \vec{q}_{i}\right\}\right)O({p​i​,q​i​}), defined in phase space. In quantum mechanics, these functions are replaced by Hermitian matrices (operators) in Hilbert space, obtained by substituting operators for {q⃗i}\left\{\vec{q}_{i}\right\}{q​i​} and {p⃗i}\left\{\vec{p}_{i}\right\}{p​i​} in the classical expression (after proper symmetrization of products, e.g. pq→(pq+qp)/2)p q \rightarrow(p q+q p) / 2)pq→(pq+qp)/2). These basic operators satisfy the commutation relations,
[pj,qk]≡pjqk−qkpj=ℏiδj,k\left[p_{j}, q_{k}\right] \equiv p_{j} q_{k}-q_{k} p_{j}=\frac{\hbar}{i} \delta_{j, k}[pj​,qk​]≡pj​qk​−qk​pj​=iℏ​δj,k​

For example, in the coordinate basis ∣{q⃗i}⟩\left|\left\{\vec{q}_{i}\right\}\right\rangle∣{q​i​}⟩, the momentum operators are

pj=ℏi∂∂qjp_{j}=\frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{\partial}{\partial q_{j}}pj​=iℏ​∂qj​∂​

(Note that classical Poisson brackets satisfy {pj,qk}=−δj,k.\left\{p_{j}, q_{k}\right\}=-\delta_{j, k} .{pj​,qk​}=−δj,k​. Quite generally, quantum commutation relations are obtained by multiplying the corresponding classical Poisson brackets by iℏ.)i \hbar .)iℏ.)

  • Unlike in classical mechanics, the value of an operator O\mathcal{O}O is not uniquely determined for a particular micro-state. It is instead a random variable, whose average in a state ∣Ψ⟩|\Psi\rangle∣Ψ⟩ is given by
⟨O⟩≡⟨Ψ∣O∣Ψ⟩≡∑m,n⟨Ψ∣m⟩⟨m∣O∣n⟩⟨n∣Ψ⟩\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle \equiv\langle\Psi|\mathcal{O}| \Psi\rangle \equiv \sum_{m, n}\langle\Psi \mid m\rangle\langle m|\mathcal{O}| n\rangle\langle n \mid \Psi\rangle⟨O⟩≡⟨Ψ∣O∣Ψ⟩≡m,n∑​⟨Ψ∣m⟩⟨m∣O∣n⟩⟨n∣Ψ⟩

For example,

⟨U({q⃗})⟩=∫∏i=1Nd3q⃗iΨ∗U({q⃗})Ψ, and ⟨K({p⃗})⟩=∫∏i=1Nd3q⃗iΨ∗K({ℏiddq⃗})Ψ\begin{aligned} &\langle U(\{\vec{q}\})\rangle=\int \prod_{i=1}^{N} d^{3} \vec{q}_{i} \Psi^{*} U(\{\vec{q}\}) \Psi, \quad \text { and } \\ &\langle K(\{\vec{p}\})\rangle=\int \prod_{i=1}^{N} d^{3} \vec{q}_{i} \Psi^{*} K\left(\left\{\frac{\hbar}{i} \frac{d}{d \vec{q}}\right\}\right) \Psi \end{aligned}​⟨U({q​})⟩=∫i=1∏N​d3q​i​Ψ∗U({q​})Ψ, and ⟨K({p​})⟩=∫i=1∏N​d3q​i​Ψ∗K({iℏ​dq​d​})Ψ​

To ensure that the expectation value ⟨O⟩\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle⟨O⟩ is real, the operators O\mathcal{O}O must be Hermitian, i.e. satisfy

O†=O, where ⟨m∣O†∣n⟩≡⟨n∣O∣m⟩∗\mathcal{O}^{\dagger}=\mathcal{O}, \quad \text { where } \quad\left\langle m\left|\mathcal{O}^{\dagger}\right| n\right\rangle \equiv\langle n|\mathcal{O}| m\rangle^{*}O†=O, where ⟨m∣∣∣​O†∣∣∣​n⟩≡⟨n∣O∣m⟩∗

When replacing p⃗\vec{p}p​ and q⃗\vec{q}q​ in a classical operator O({p⃗i,q⃗i})\mathcal{O}\left(\left\{\vec{p}_{i}, \vec{q}_{i}\right\}\right)O({p​i​,q​i​}) by corresponding matrices, proper symmetrization of various products is necessary to ensure the above Hermiticity.

Time evolution of micro-states is governed by the Hamiltonian H({p⃗i,q⃗i}).\mathcal{H}\left(\left\{\vec{p}_{i}, \vec{q}_{i}\right\}\right) .H({p​i​,q​i​}). A classical microstate evolves according to Hamilton's equations of motion, while in quantum mechanics the state vector changes in time according to

iℏ∂∂t∣Ψ(t)⟩=H∣Ψ(t)⟩i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}|\Psi(t)\rangle=\mathcal{H}|\Psi(t)\rangleiℏ∂t∂​∣Ψ(t)⟩=H∣Ψ(t)⟩

A convenient basis is one that diagonalizes the matrix H\mathcal{H}H. The energy eigen-states satisfy H∣n⟩=En∣n⟩\mathcal{H}|n\rangle=\mathcal{E}_{n}|n\rangleH∣n⟩=En​∣n⟩, where En\mathcal{E}_{n}En​ are the eigen-energies. Substituting ∣Ψ(t)⟩=∑n⟨n∣Ψ(t)⟩∣n⟩|\Psi(t)\rangle=\sum_{n}\langle n \mid \Psi(t)\rangle|n\rangle∣Ψ(t)⟩=∑n​⟨n∣Ψ(t)⟩∣n⟩ in eq.(VI.69), and taking advantage of the ortho-normality condition ⟨m∣n⟩=δm,n\langle m \mid n\rangle=\delta_{m, n}⟨m∣n⟩=δm,n​, yields

iℏddt⟨n∣Ψ(t)⟩=En⟨n∣Ψ(t)⟩,⟹⟨n∣Ψ(t)⟩=exp⁡(−iEntℏ)⟨n∣Ψ(0)⟩i \hbar \frac{d}{d t}\langle n \mid \Psi(t)\rangle=\mathcal{E}_{n}\langle n \mid \Psi(t)\rangle, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad\langle n \mid \Psi(t)\rangle=\exp \left(-\frac{i \mathcal{E}_{n} t}{\hbar}\right)\langle n \mid \Psi(0)\rangleiℏdtd​⟨n∣Ψ(t)⟩=En​⟨n∣Ψ(t)⟩,⟹⟨n∣Ψ(t)⟩=exp(−ℏiEn​t​)⟨n∣Ψ(0)⟩

The quantum states at two different times can be related by a time evolution operator, as

∣Ψ(t)⟩=U(t,t0)∣Ψ(t0)⟩|\Psi(t)\rangle=U\left(t, t_{0}\right)\left|\Psi\left(t_{0}\right)\right\rangle∣Ψ(t)⟩=U(t,t0​)∣Ψ(t0​)⟩

which satisfies iℏ∂tU(t,t0)=HU(t,t0)i \hbar \partial_{t} U\left(t, t_{0}\right)=\mathcal{H} U\left(t, t_{0}\right)iℏ∂t​U(t,t0​)=HU(t,t0​), with the boundary condition U(t0,t0)=1.U\left(t_{0}, t_{0}\right)=1 .U(t0​,t0​)=1. If H\mathcal{H}H is independent of ttt, we can solve these equations to yield

U(t,t0)=exp⁡[−iℏH(t−t0)]U\left(t, t_{0}\right)=\exp \left[-\frac{i}{\hbar} \mathcal{H}\left(t-t_{0}\right)\right]U(t,t0​)=exp[−ℏi​H(t−t0​)]

\section{VI.E Quantum macrostates}

Macro-states of the system depend on only a few thermodynamic functions. We can form an ensemble of a large number N\mathcal{N}N, of micro-states μα\mu_{\alpha}μα​, corresponding to a given macrostate. The different micro-states occur with probabilities pα.p_{\alpha} .pα​. (For example pα=1/Np_{\alpha}=1 / \mathcal{N}pα​=1/N in the absence of any other information.) When we no longer have exact knowledge of the microstate, it is said to be in a mixed state.

Classically, ensemble averages are calculated from

O({p⃗i,q⃗i})t‾=∑αpαO(μα(t))=∫∏i=1Nd3p⃗id3qi→O({p⃗i,q⃗i})ρ({p⃗i,q⃗i},t)\overline{\mathcal{O}\left(\left\{\vec{p}_{i}, \vec{q}_{i}\right\}\right)_{t}}=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha} \mathcal{O}\left(\mu_{\alpha}(t)\right)=\int \prod_{i=1}^{N} d^{3} \vec{p}_{i} d^{3} \overrightarrow{q_{i}} \mathcal{O}\left(\left\{\vec{p}_{i}, \vec{q}_{i}\right\}\right) \rho\left(\left\{\vec{p}_{i}, \vec{q}_{i}\right\}, t\right)O({p​i​,q​i​})t​​=α∑​pα​O(μα​(t))=∫i=1∏N​d3p​i​d3qi​​O({p​i​,q​i​})ρ({p​i​,q​i​},t)

where

ρ({p⃗i,q⃗i},t)=∑αpα∏i=1Nδ3(q⃗i−q⃗i(t)α)δ3(p⃗i−p⃗i(t)α)\rho\left(\left\{\vec{p}_{i}, \vec{q}_{i}\right\}, t\right)=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha} \prod_{i=1}^{N} \delta^{3}\left(\vec{q}_{i}-\vec{q}_{i}(t)_{\alpha}\right) \delta^{3}\left(\vec{p}_{i}-\vec{p}_{i}(t)_{\alpha}\right)ρ({p​i​,q​i​},t)=α∑​pα​i=1∏N​δ3(q​i​−q​i​(t)α​)δ3(p​i​−p​i​(t)α​)

is the ensemble density.

Similarly, a mixed quantum state is obtained from a set of possible states {∣ψα⟩}\left\{\left|\psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle\right\}{∣ψα​⟩}, with probabilities {pα}\left\{p_{\alpha}\right\}{pα​}. The ensemble average of the quantum mechanical expectation value in eq.(VI.67) is then given by

⟨O⟩‾=∑αpα⟨Ψα∣O∣Ψα⟩=∑α,m,npα⟨Ψα∣m⟩⟨n∣Ψα⟩⟨m∣O∣n⟩=∑m,n⟨n∣ρ∣m⟩⟨m∣O∣n⟩=tr⁡(ρO)\begin{aligned} \overline{\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle} &=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha}|\mathcal{O}| \Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle=\sum_{\alpha, m, n} p_{\alpha}\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha} \mid m\right\rangle\left\langle n \mid \Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle\langle m|\mathcal{O}| n\rangle \\ &=\sum_{m, n}\langle n|\rho| m\rangle\langle m|\mathcal{O}| n\rangle=\operatorname{tr}(\rho \mathcal{O}) \end{aligned}⟨O⟩​​=α∑​pα​⟨Ψα​∣O∣Ψα​⟩=α,m,n∑​pα​⟨Ψα​∣m⟩⟨n∣Ψα​⟩⟨m∣O∣n⟩=m,n∑​⟨n∣ρ∣m⟩⟨m∣O∣n⟩=tr(ρO)​

where we have introduced a basis {∣n⟩}\{|n\rangle\}{∣n⟩}, and defined the density matrix

⟨n∣ρ(t)∣m⟩≡∑αpα⟨n∣Ψα(t)⟩⟨Ψα(t)∣m⟩\langle n|\rho(t)| m\rangle \equiv \sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left\langle n \mid \Psi_{\alpha}(t)\right\rangle\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha}(t) \mid m\right\rangle⟨n∣ρ(t)∣m⟩≡α∑​pα​⟨n∣Ψα​(t)⟩⟨Ψα​(t)∣m⟩

Classically, the probability (density) ρ(t)\rho(t)ρ(t) is a function defined on phase space. As all operators in phase space, it is replaced by a matrix in quantum mechanics. Stripped of the choice of basis, the density matrix is

ρ(t)=∑αpα∣Ψα(t)⟩⟨Ψα(t)∣\rho(t)=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left|\Psi_{\alpha}(t)\right\rangle\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha}(t)\right|ρ(t)=α∑​pα​∣Ψα​(t)⟩⟨Ψα​(t)∣

Clearly, ρ\rhoρ corresponds to a pure state if and only if ρ2=ρ\rho^{2}=\rhoρ2=ρ

The density matrix satisfies the following properties:

(i) Normalization: Since each ∣Ψα⟩\left|\Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle∣Ψα​⟩ is normalized to unity,

⟨1⟩=tr⁡(ρ)=∑n⟨n∣ρ∣n⟩=∑α,npα∣⟨n∣Ψα⟩∣2=∑αpα=1\langle 1\rangle=\operatorname{tr}(\rho)=\sum_{n}\langle n|\rho| n\rangle=\sum_{\alpha, n} p_{\alpha}\left|\left\langle n \mid \Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle\right|^{2}=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}=1⟨1⟩=tr(ρ)=n∑​⟨n∣ρ∣n⟩=α,n∑​pα​∣⟨n∣Ψα​⟩∣2=α∑​pα​=1

(ii) Hermiticity: The density matrix is Hermitian, i.e. ρ†=ρ\rho^{\dagger}=\rhoρ†=ρ, since

⟨m∣ρ†∣n⟩=⟨n∣ρ∣m⟩∗=∑αpα⟨Ψα∣m⟩⟨n∣Ψα⟩=⟨n∣ρ∣m⟩\left\langle m\left|\rho^{\dagger}\right| n\right\rangle=\langle n|\rho| m\rangle^{*}=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha} \mid m\right\rangle\left\langle n \mid \Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle=\langle n|\rho| m\rangle⟨m∣∣∣​ρ†∣∣∣​n⟩=⟨n∣ρ∣m⟩∗=α∑​pα​⟨Ψα​∣m⟩⟨n∣Ψα​⟩=⟨n∣ρ∣m⟩

ensuring that the averages in eq.(VI.76) are real numbers.

(iii) Positivity: For any ∣Φ⟩|\Phi\rangle∣Φ⟩,

⟨Φ∣ρ∣Φ⟩=∑αpα⟨Φ∣Ψα⟩⟨Ψα∣Φ⟩=∑αpα∣⟨Φ∣Ψα⟩∣2≥0\langle\Phi|\rho| \Phi\rangle=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left\langle\Phi \mid \Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha} \mid \Phi\right\rangle=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left|\left\langle\Phi \mid \Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle\right|^{2} \geq 0⟨Φ∣ρ∣Φ⟩=α∑​pα​⟨Φ∣Ψα​⟩⟨Ψα​∣Φ⟩=α∑​pα​∣⟨Φ∣Ψα​⟩∣2≥0

Thus ρ\rhoρ is positive definite, implying that all its eigenvalues must be positive.

  • Liouville's theorem governs the time evolution of the classical density as
dρdt=∂ρ∂t−{H,ρ}=0\frac{d \rho}{d t}=\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}-\{\mathcal{H}, \rho\}=0dtdρ​=∂t∂ρ​−{H,ρ}=0

It is most convenient to examine the evolution of the quantum density matrix in the basis of energy eigen-states, where according to eq.(VI.70)

iℏ∂∂t⟨n∣ρ(t)∣m⟩=iℏ∂∂t∑αpα⟨n∣Ψα(t)⟩⟨Ψα(t)∣m⟩=∑αpα[(En−Em)⟨n∣Ψα⟩⟨Ψα∣m⟩]=⟨n∣(Hρ−ρH)∣m⟩\begin{aligned} i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\langle n|\rho(t)| m\rangle &=i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left\langle n \mid \Psi_{\alpha}(t)\right\rangle\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha}(t) \mid m\right\rangle \\ &=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left[\left(\mathcal{E}_{n}-\mathcal{E}_{m}\right)\left\langle n \mid \Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha} \mid m\right\rangle\right] \\ &=\langle n|(\mathcal{H} \rho-\rho \mathcal{H})| m\rangle \end{aligned}iℏ∂t∂​⟨n∣ρ(t)∣m⟩​=iℏ∂t∂​α∑​pα​⟨n∣Ψα​(t)⟩⟨Ψα​(t)∣m⟩=α∑​pα​[(En​−Em​)⟨n∣Ψα​⟩⟨Ψα​∣m⟩]=⟨n∣(Hρ−ρH)∣m⟩​

The final result is a tensorial identity, and hence, independent of the choice of basis

iℏ∂∂tρ=[H,ρ]i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \rho=[\mathcal{H}, \rho]iℏ∂t∂​ρ=[H,ρ]

Equilibrium requires time independent averages, and suggests ∂ρ/∂t=0.\partial \rho / \partial t=0 .∂ρ/∂t=0. This condition is satisfied in both eqs.(VI.81) and (VI.83) by choosing ρ=ρ(H).\rho=\rho(\mathcal{H}) .ρ=ρ(H). (As discussed in chapter III, ρ\rhoρ may also depend on conserved quantities such that [H,L]=0.)[\mathcal{H}, L]=0 .)[H,L]=0.) Various equilibrium quantum density matrices can now be constructed in analogy to classical statistical mechanics.

  • Microcanonical ensemble: As the internal energy has a fixed value EEE, a density matrix that includes this constraint is
ρ(E)=δ(H−E)Ω(E)\rho(E)=\frac{\delta(\mathcal{H}-E)}{\Omega(E)}ρ(E)=Ω(E)δ(H−E)​

In particular, in the basis of energy eigen-states,

⟨n∣ρ∣m⟩=∑αpα⟨n∣Ψα⟩⟨Ψα∣m⟩={1Ω if En=E, and m=n0 if En≠E, or m≠n\langle n|\rho| m\rangle=\sum_{\alpha} p_{\alpha}\left\langle n \mid \Psi_{\alpha}\right\rangle\left\langle\Psi_{\alpha} \mid m\right\rangle= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{\Omega} & \text { if } \mathcal{E}_{n}=E, \text { and } m=n \\ 0 & \text { if } \mathcal{E}_{n} \neq E, \text { or } m \neq n\end{cases}⟨n∣ρ∣m⟩=α∑​pα​⟨n∣Ψα​⟩⟨Ψα​∣m⟩={Ω1​0​ if En​=E, and m=n if En​=E, or m=n​

The first condition states that only eigen-states of the correct energy can appear in the quantum wave-function, and that (for pα=1/N)\left.p_{\alpha}=1 / \mathcal{N}\right)pα​=1/N) such states on average have the same amplitude, ⟨n∣Ψ⟩∣2‾=1/Ω.\overline{\left.\langle n \mid \Psi\rangle\right|^{2}}=1 / \Omega .⟨n∣Ψ⟩∣2​=1/Ω. This is equivalent to the classical postulate of equal a priori equilibrium probabilities. The second (additional) condition states that the Ω\OmegaΩ eigen-states of energy EEE are combined in a typical micro-state with independent random phases. (Note that the normalization condition tr⁡ρ=1\operatorname{tr} \rho=1trρ=1, implies that Ω(E)=∑nδ(E−En)\Omega(E)=\sum_{n} \delta\left(E-E_{n}\right)Ω(E)=∑n​δ(E−En​) is the number of eigen-states of H\mathcal{H}H with energy E.)E .)E.)

  • Canonical ensemble: A fixed temperature T=1/kBβT=1 / k_{B} \betaT=1/kB​β, can be achieved by putting the system in contact with a reservoir. By considering the combined system, the canonical density matrix is obtained as
ρ(β)=exp⁡(−βH)Z(β)\rho(\beta)=\frac{\exp (-\beta \mathcal{H})}{Z(\beta)}ρ(β)=Z(β)exp(−βH)​

The normalization condition tr⁡(ρ)=1\operatorname{tr}(\rho)=1tr(ρ)=1, leads to the quantum partition function

Z=tr⁡(e−βH)=∑ne−βEnZ=\operatorname{tr}\left(e^{-\beta \mathcal{H}}\right)=\sum_{n} e^{-\beta \mathcal{E}_{n}}Z=tr(e−βH)=n∑​e−βEn​

The final sum is over the (discrete) energy levels of H\mathcal{H}H, and justifies the calculations performed in the previous sections.

  • Grand Canonical Ensemble: The number of particles NNN, is no longer fixed. Quantum micro-states with indefinite particle number span a so called Fock space. The density matrix is
ρ(β,μ)=e−βH+βμNQ, where Q(β,μ)=tr⁡(e−βH+βμN)=∑N=0∞eβμNZN(β)\rho(\beta, \mu)=\frac{e^{-\beta \mathcal{H}+\beta \mu N}}{\mathcal{Q}}, \quad \text { where } \quad \mathcal{Q}(\beta, \mu)=\operatorname{tr}\left(e^{-\beta \mathcal{H}+\beta \mu N}\right)=\sum_{N=0}^{\infty} e^{\beta \mu N} Z_{N}(\beta)ρ(β,μ)=Qe−βH+βμN​, where Q(β,μ)=tr(e−βH+βμN)=N=0∑∞​eβμNZN​(β)

Example: Consider a single particle in a quantum canonical ensemble in a box of volume VVV. The energy eigen-states of the Hamiltonian

obtained from H1∣k⃗⟩=E(k⃗)∣k⃗⟩\mathcal{H}_{1}|\vec{k}\rangle=\mathcal{E}(\vec{k})|\vec{k}\rangleH1​∣k⟩=E(k)∣k⟩, are

noteIndex.body:
# Introduction to Tex Decks!

TexDeck.net is a collection of resources assembled to make LaTeX rich flashcards easier to write, remix, and organize.

The effect: Low cost active learning, allowing one's knowledge of science to scale sustainably.

A [[case study]] is in progress to seed the flashcard repository using a course in [nanoelectronics](https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-701-introduction-to-nanoelectronics-spring-2010/) from [OpenCourseWare](https://ocw.mit.edu/)

((ref:[[case study.1 motivation]]))

### How does the system work?

....

### Intellectual Property

All work is [CC-BY-SA 4.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/) unless otherwise specified at the top of a page. I cannot really enforce the attribution clause, but I do highly reccomend it. If you find these resources useful, consider sharing them with others.

Also, keep in mind that this is a work in progress and may contain errors. [Pull requests on these study resources](https://github.com/Stedag/ocwphy) are encouraged.

Despite accumulating a good deal of notes as part of my B.S. I will not include any of school notes among these resources to honor copyright agreements with my department. Nonetheless I forsee monotonic aggregation of resources organized around OCW classes or open-access textbooks.

For any concerns regarding IP, open an issue on github.
